bestBHT.bht: Do not let your strength of faith pass into bad repute; use it in a way that honors and encourages others, rather than causing harm or giving occasion for unkind remarks. This exhortation applies to the Christian liberty and freedom that some may have, which may grieve and lead to censure from weaker brethren. Therefore, prioritize the good of religion and peace over personal indulgence, abstaining from things of indifference for the sake of others. Do not let your good and lawful liberty be evil spoken of by being offensive to others.

Henry Alford: 16.] Your strength of faith is a good thing; let it not pass into bad repute: use it so that it may be honoured, and encourage others.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let not then your good—that is, this liberty of yours as to Jewish meats and days, well founded though it be.
Be evil spoken of—for the evil it does to others.
Albert Barnes: You should not make such a use of [Christian liberty] as to do injury to others."
Do not so use your Christian liberty as to give occasion for railing and unkind remarks from your brethren, so as to produce contention and strife."
In such a case we should yield our private, unimportant personal indulgence to the good of the cause of religion and of peace.
Marvin Vincent: Your good [υμων το αγαθον]. Referring, most probably, to the liberty of the strong.
Others think that the whole Church is addressed, in which case good would refer to the gospel doctrine.
In 1 Corinthians 10:30, it is used of evil-speaking by members of the Church, which favors the reference of good to the strong.
Philip Schaff: Let not than your good be evil spoken of, lit, ‘blasphemed.’
The exhortation may be applied to the strong; ‘good’ referring accordingly to their Christian liberty, or strength of faith, which grieved the weak brethren, and would lead to censure.
Those who ‘blasphemed’ would be such of the outside heathen world as noticed the discord.
Archibald T. Robertson: Your good (υμων το αγαθον). 'The good thing of you' = the liberty or Christian freedom which you claim.
Be evil spoken of (βλασφημεισθω). Present passive imperative of βλασφημεω for which see Matthew 9:3; Romans 3:8.
John Gill: The sense is the same, and to be understood either of the Gospel in general, which is good in its author, matter, effects, and consequences; is good tidings of good things, and which might be blasphemed by the men of the world.
Christ has procured it, and bestows it upon his people; it is a valuable blessing in itself, and is attended and followed with many considerable privileges and immunities.

Forego the use of it, in things of an indifferent nature; so that this is another of the apostle's reasons, why though nothing is of itself unclean, yet it should be abstained from on account of others.
John Wesley: Let not then your good and lawful liberty be evil spoken of - By being offensive to others.

bhtAttempts.bht: Do not let your strength of faith pass into bad repute; use it in a way that honors and encourages others, rather than causing harm or giving occasion for unkind remarks. This exhortation applies to the Christian liberty and freedom that some may have, which may grieve and lead to censure from weaker brethren or even those in the outside world. Therefore, it is important to prioritize the good of the cause of religion and peace over personal indulgence, abstaining from things of indifference for the sake of others. Let us not allow our good and lawful liberty to be evil spoken of by being offensive to others.

Do not let your good and lawful liberty be evil spoken of by being offensive to others.

Do not let your good and lawful liberty be evil spoken of by being offensive to others.
